initiativeCore.problemStatement: Users need a browser-based web application to access their PC camera, view live feed, and capture photos and videos through a simple, intuitive interface.
goals: Enable users to activate their PC camera from within a web browser
Allow users to capture still photos from the camera feed in JPEG format
Allow users to record video from the camera feed in MP4 format (or WebM for Safari)
Support video recordings up to 30 minutes in length
Provide intuitive and easy-to-use interface for camera selection and capture
Support maximum available camera resolution including 720p, 1080p, and 4K
nonGoals: File formats other than JPEG (photos) and MP4/WebM (videos)
Compliance with specific regulatory frameworks (HIPAA, GDPR data retention, etc.)
Custom download folder selection by user
Support for cameras with resolution lower than 720p
initiativeCore.businessImpact: Success enables users to perform basic media capture tasks directly in the browser without installing native applications, reducing friction and improving accessibility. Failure results in users seeking alternative solutions or abandoning the workflow entirely.
initiativeCore.stakeholders: Primary stakeholder: Initiative requester (self). End users requiring browser-based camera access, development team, QA team. Stakeholder approval is sufficient for launch decision.

functional.description: Application must run in modern web browsers without requiring plugins or extensions
Provide a button to request and enable PC camera access
Display live camera feed in real-time once camera is enabled
Provide a photo capture button positioned to the right side of the camera feed
Provide a video capture button positioned below the camera feed
Capture and save still images in JPEG format when photo button is clicked
Start and stop video recording in MP4 format (or WebM for Safari) when video button is clicked
Automatically download captured photos to browser's default download folder
Automatically download recorded videos to browser's default download folder
Display visual feedback when camera is active
Handle camera permission denial gracefully with user messaging
Provide a camera selector dropdown displaying camera names when multiple cameras are available
Position camera selector above the capture buttons
Support video recordings up to 30 minutes maximum duration
Prevent video recording from exceeding 30-minute limit with appropriate user notification
Display recording duration timer during video capture
Allow users to switch between available cameras using the selector
Generate file names using format: CamerApp-YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS.extension (e.g., CamerApp-2026-02-10-183648.jpg)
Display error message and allow user to choose different folder when download folder is inaccessible
Cancel active recording and discard buffered data when user closes browser tab during recording
Continue recording when user switches to another browser tab (recording persists until 30-minute limit)
Request maximum available camera resolution (720p, 1080p, or 4K based on camera capabilities)
Display human-understandable error messages for all error conditions
Disable photo capture button when video recording is in progress
Debounce photo capture to prevent serial captures faster than 1 per second
Display error message when camera resolution is below 720p minimum requirement
Allow 4K video recording to continue for full 30 minutes even if system resources are constrained

Application must support browser versions released from January 2025 onwards

Browser memory limits reached during long video recording
MP4 encoding fails or is not supported by browser (fallback to WebM for Safari)
JPEG encoding produces corrupted image file
Camera supports 4K resolution but browser or system cannot handle it (allow recording to continue)
File name collision when multiple captures occur in same second (prevented by 1-second debounce)
User switches between tabs rapidly during recording
System clock is incorrect resulting in wrong timestamps in filenames
Camera provides resolution lower than requested maximum
Browser version is older than January 2025 releases
User rapidly clicks photo button multiple times (debounced to 1 per second)
Camera resolution is below 720p minimum (display error, not supported)
4K video recording on minimum hardware (2GB RAM, 2-core CPU) for full 30 minutes
Large video file sizes approaching browser or filesystem limits (no size limit imposed)

deliveryIntent.rolloutExpectations: Single release next week with core camera access, live feed display at maximum available resolution (720p/1080p/4K), camera selection, and photo/video capture functionality. Files automatically download as JPEG (photos) and MP4 or WebM (videos) to browser's default download folder with standardized naming format (CamerApp-YYYY-MM-DD-HHMMSS.extension). Support for up to 30-minute video recordings with proper tab closure/switching behavior. Photo capture disabled during video recording. Photo capture debounced to maximum 1 per second. Video uses standard bitrates for selected resolution. Minimum hardware: 2GB RAM, 2-core CPU, 720p camera. Cameras below 720p not supported. Error handling includes folder selection when default download location inaccessible. No file size limitations within 30-minute constraint. Advanced features like editing, filters, or cloud storage deferred to future iterations. Stakeholder approval sufficient for launch.
deliveryIntent.timelineAssumptions: Target delivery: next week (approximately 5-7 calendar days). Assumes focused development sprint with daily progress checks. Timeline is aggressive and requires immediate start, dedicated resources, and minimal scope changes. Cross-browser testing must occur in parallel with development. Testing must cover browser versions from January 2025 onwards. Testing must validate 4K recording on minimum hardware specifications.
